title: Gold price soars to $US5300, but will Aussie dollar rally continue?
text:
The price of gold has continued to soar, hitting ﻿$US5300 an ounce overnight, driven by a plunging US dollar and geopolitical uncertainty.

The greenback slumped to its lowest value in nearly four years after US President Donald Trump declared this week he was not worried about the value of the American currency.

Adding to concerns on financial markets has been Trump's decision overnight to send a huge naval force towards Iran, and threatening an attack on the Middle Eastern state unless a nuclear deal is achieved.﻿

The price of gold bullion has jumped to $US5300. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

How long can Aussie dollar surge last?﻿

Australia's dollar, meanwhile, has risen to its highest level against its US counterpart since February 2023, buying 70.11 US cents yesterday after climbing 1.4 per cent.

But economists are uncertain whether the jump against the greenback will continue for the rest of this year.

A Commonwealth Bank of Australia investor update today says it would take a "significant shift" in economic fundamentals, such as the value of Aussie shares and commodity prices, for the dollar to achieve 75 US cents.

Instead, the bank expects the currency to trade at 70 cents against the greenback for some time.

"We expect AUD/USD to decline as 2026 progresses."﻿

So it may be better to book that trip to the US sooner, rather than later.

The US Navy's nuclear-powered aircraft carrier USS Nimitz is part of a huge force heading to Iran. (Cha Geun-ho/Yonhap via AP) (AP)

Gold 'could hit ﻿US$6000'

The surge in gold prices and falling US dollar mark a flight from currencies and sovereign bonds - or debt securities issued by national governments, according to experts.

The chief executive of UK-based global financial advisory firm de Vere Group, Nigel Green, believes gold could reach $US6000 by the end of this year.

"Gold benefits when political signals create uncertainty about growth, inflation, and international cooperation," ﻿he said.

The jump in gold also reflects mounting concern in financial markets over government borrowing as debt levels across major economies continue to rise.

Also propelling central banks and investors to seek refuge in gold has been uncertainty in key bond markets, such as Japan.

Green believes this week's spike in the gold price is more than a blip.

"The $US5000 milestone marks a beginning rather than an endpoint. We believe $US6000 is not unrealistic by the end of the year."

title: The biggest video games set to be released this year
text:
2 of 21 Attribution: Rockstar

After multiple delays, the generation defining Grand Theft Auto series is finally expected to release its next mainline game this year.

Set in a modern day Vice City, Grand Theft Auto VI is said to be the biggest GTA game ever. There's two playable characters: Jason Duval, a former drug runner, and Lucia Caminos, fresh out of prison and on a mission.

READ MORE: Most anticipated video game of all time delayed yet again﻿

These two look to have fantastic chemistry, how their story unfolds is the big question. Swamps, beaches, city streets and national parks — from what's been shown so far, the game environments have never looked better.

Paired with an abundance of new and interesting characters, it's no wonder they're taking their time to put it all together.

GTA VI is now set to release on November 19 across PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S consoles.

title: Sally is being evicted her 'dream' home after sudden rule change
text:
Dozens of houseboat residents and boat owners are facing imminent eviction from a popular Queensland river following the introduction of an anchoring time limit.

Unmoored boats larger than five metres on the Noosa River can only stay for a maximum of 28 days per year from January 1, 2026, according to a rule announced by the Maritime Safety Queensland (MSQ) , meaning many long-term houseboat owners need to leave this week.

It has triggered outrage among members of the Noosa River community, some of whom have lived there for decades, who say the cost of relocation is prohibitively expensive.

Unmoored boats larger than five metres on the Noosa River can now only stay for a maximum of 28 days per year. One of the boats on Noosa River pictured above. (Supplied)

Do you have a story? Contact reporter April Glover at april.glover@nine.com.au

Sally White, 62, has been living in her houseboat since 2021.

She told nine.com.au it was her "dream" to live aboard a floating home – but that dream is being ripped away.

"I was being priced out of the rental market and this was the next best thing. It had been one of those fantasies, a dream," White said.

Sally White has been living on the Noosa River for five years. (Supplied)

"﻿It's certainly not a walk in the park by any stretch of the imagination. Everyone thinks we're slumming it, or we're freeloaders.

"I still pay my taxes, and the money that I save from not paying rates, goes to the maintenance of the boat to make sure she is still compliant and she still floats."

White, like many other residents on the Noosa River, needs to move her home of nearly five years to another waterway or she could face hefty fines.

She has applied for a special extension but worries it will be denied.

﻿"I would have to look at getting some funds, maybe from my superannuation," she added.

"It just smacks of elitism. Which I think is sad."﻿

White has now put her boat on the market, however acknowledges it will be a tough sell given the anchoring deadline.

READ MORE: ﻿ Frantic dual citizens scramble to order passports amid major change

White's houseboat (pictured above) is her dream home. (Supplied)

She has applied for a special extension but worries it will be denied. (Supplied)

Fellow boat owner Sally Hayes has been a vocal opponent of MSQ's new rules.

She ﻿recently moved onto her houseboat while she looks for a rental home.

"It's just financially ridiculous when you think about it," Hayes said.

"It's going to cost, to guess, for a bigger houseboat, around $20,000 to move a boat off the river. That's prohibitive.

"There's been absolutely no support in relocation of the vessels."

Hayes took on the task of informing every owner of﻿ a vessel bigger than five metres of the MSQ deadline.

She estimates around 80 boats on the river are captured under the new rule, with around 27 full-time residents impacted.

Sally Hayes is a vocal opponent of the new rule. (Supplied)

"Most of these people who live aboard or have these boats have spent upward of $100,000 or $150,000," she said.

"Suddenly, by this ruling being put in place, it renders these boats as worthless.

"There are quite a few people who are happy to move - if they had the means. But they don't have the means, they don't have $20,000 or $30,000 to spare."﻿

Some residents on the Noosa River have lived there for decades, Hayes said.

﻿Hayes is calling on the Queensland government to either reverse the decision or provide financial assistance to relocate boats.

She warned the changes ﻿will ruin the Noosa River for residents and holidaymakers.

"They're the colourful fabric of Noosa," she said.

"The whole river environment is just being absolutely ripped apart."

Boats secured to private jetties are not considered anchored and a﻿re not subject to the rules.

There are only a limited number of moor﻿ings on the river, though.

"If the moorings were made available to people like myself, I would jump on it. I'd be happy to pay for it," Hayes added.

"But I was told, 'don't even bother going on the mooring list because we've got a wait list of over 10 years'."

The 28-day rule applies to Noosa River and all adjoining waters, including Noosa Sound, Lake Cooroibah, Lake Cootharabah, Lake Doonella, Lake Weyba, the Everglades and connected creeks.

A sign posted on a boat anchored at Noosa River. (Supplied)

Maritime Safety Queensland's statement in full:

The Noosa River Management Plan aims to make the Noosa River safer, cleaner and more sustainable, ensuring it remains a key part of Noosa's appeal for years to come.

The plan, introduced in 2023 after extensive community consultation since 2021, focuses on reducing congestion, improving safety and protecting the environment on this popular waterway.

Maritime Safety Queensland has implemented the Management Plan in carefully considered stages, commencing in September 2023, with each subsequent stage announced 3-6 months in advance.

The Noosa River Management Plan balances the competing needs of vessel owners, other river users and tourists, local community residents and businesses.

The new 28-day anchoring restrictions introduced on 1 January 2026 are designed to ensure the river can still be safely enjoyed by all of the community and not used as a long-term vessel storage facility.

Of the 120 vessels still anchored in the Noosa River, MSQ estimates the number of full-time live-aboard vessels still in the river to be around 20, with another 9 used as weekend or part-time accommodation.

title: 'Doesn't make any sense': Forgotten HECS detail delaying money in your pocket
text:
T﻿he federal government's 20 per cent HECS reduction scheme has resulted in some Australian taxpayers inadvertently losing unnecessary money from their paycheques.

Nearly three million Australians have an average of $5500 in HECS debts owing to the government – and this debt is paid off slowly through compulsory repayments.

The relief was applied to balances that were still active on June 1, 2025 and has helped some taxpayers clear their debt after years.

READ MORE: Scientists set a new time for the Doomsday Clock

Around three million Australians have an average of $5,500 in HECS debts. (Getty)

But if you've forgotten to tell your employer to stop garnishing your wages for fully-paid HECS debts, you might need to act fast.

﻿Director of Tax Communication at H&R Block Mark Chapman told nine.com.au that Australians who don't stop redundant repayments are essentially giving the federal government a no-strings-attached loan.

"If you do overpay, the money isn't lost, but you won't actually see it again until tax time," Chapman explained.

"You have to lodge your tax return, and at that point, the ATO will repay it. But that does mean that there will be quite a lengthy delay.

"You're basically just using the money to make a free loan to the government, which doesn't make any sense."

Australian pool manager Maddie paid off her $12,000 HECS debt late last year.

She told nine.com.au ﻿the 20 per cent reduction shaved off around $2500 from her balance, meaning she could make one voluntary payment and reduce it to zero.

Maddie hasn't told her employer about paying it off yet.

"There's very little clear or accessible information about paying off HECS – especially about what steps to take once it's fully cleared," she said.

"﻿The lack of guidance makes it confusing and easy to miss important steps."

She expects a hefty tax return come June 30.

Maddie paid off her $12,000 HECS debt in December 2025. (Supplied)

HECS debt repayments don't automatically stop even if you log onto MyGov and find the balance has reached zero, Chapman said.

You need to fill out a tax form ﻿called a "withholding declaration", which indicates to your employer that you no longer have a HECS debt.

It's as simple as ticking the box ﻿"no" on the form when it asks if you have a Higher Education Loan Program (HELP), VET Student Loan (VSL), Financial Supplement (FS), Student Start-up Loan (SSL) or an Australian Apprenticeship Support Loan (AASL) debt.

Once this has been lodged, your next weekly, fortnightly or monthly pay will be a little bigger.

This figure will vary depending on your salary and what your regular contributions were.﻿

For example, anyone earning between $67,001 and $15,000 pays 15c for each dollar over $67000.

The HECS debt 20 per cent reductions were applied to loans last year. (Supplied)

"Say you're having $500 taken out of your salary each month to pay your HECS bill. If your HECS bill is no longer there, that $500 is paid to you in extra cash," Chapman added.

"If you told your employer that the HECS debt is gone, that immediately puts more money into your pocket.

"If you haven't yet, it's not something to panic about, but you should always make sure that you do actually notify your employer as soon as possible because that just makes financial sense for you."

If your HECS debt has reduced to a small amount, Chapman said it is important to clear it to zero before filling out the withholding declaration form.

Mark Chapman, Director of Tax Communications at H&R Block (Supplied)

"﻿If it is a bigger balance, that will actually cost you in terms of additional indexation," Chapman said.

"Your tax agent will be able to give you specific advice regarding your particular circumstances."

Maddie said it feels like a financial burden﻿ has been lifted from her shoulders after years of compulsory payments.

"Even though I didn't finish my degree, carrying a HECS debt of over $12,000 was something that weighed on me," she said.

"Paying it off feels like a massive relief. I no longer feel guilty about leaving university, and mentally it feels like closing a chapter.

"Financially, it means I can focus more on travelling and future goals without the ongoing pressure of student debt hanging over me."

The information provided on this website is general in nature only and does not constitute personal financial advice. The information has been prepared without taking into account your personal objectives, financial situation or needs. Before acting on any information on this website you should consider the appropriateness of the information having regard to your objectives, financial situation and needs.

title: Untreatable, usually fatal virus detected in India
text:
Airports across Asia are bringing in tighter screening measures after an untreatable and usually fatal disease was detected in India .

Two people have contracted Nipah virus , a zoonotic illness spread by fruit bats.

Another 196 contacts have been tested for the disease in West Bengal province, the Minister of Health said in a statement.

Nipah virus is frequently fatal and can leave survivors with brain damage. (NIAID)

"A total of 196 contacts linked to the confirmed cases have been identified, traced, monitored, and tested," the statement read.

"All traced contacts have been found asymptomatic and have tested negative for Nipah Virus Disease.

"The situation is under constant monitoring, and all necessary public health measures are in place."

Between 40 and 75 per cent of people infected by the virus do not survive, the UK Health Security Agency said.

"Some survivors may be left with lasting neurological difficulties, including persistent seizures and personality changes," the agency said in a statement.

"In rare cases, the virus can reactivate months or even years after the initial infection."

While fruit bats are natural hosts of the virus, it is capable of spreading to pigs, dogs, cats, goats, horses and sheep.

The virus can be spread from animals to humans or person-to-person via contaminated food.

Nipah virus is typically spread by fruit bats. (Adobe Stock)

The virus can often survive in fruit or fruit juice, which has been contaminated with the bodily fluids of infected bats.

The most common examples stem from the consumption of raw date palm sap.

There are documented cases of the spread of the virus between infected patients and those taking care of them.

In humans, symptoms typically appear between four and 21 days after infection.

When the symptoms do appear, they can be sudden.

Flu-like symptoms, fever and pneumonia can develop.

But the virus also commonly causes meningitis or encephalitis (swelling of the brain), conditions which are often fatal.

There is no vaccination or treatment for the virus.

Quarantine doctors watch thermal scanning of travellers from west Bengal, India at the airport in Samut Prakarn, Thailand. (AP)

Previous outbreaks have occurred in Bangladesh , Malaysia , Singapore , the Philippines and other parts of India .

Hong Kong has announced that passengers arriving from India will be screened for the virus.

"Hong Kong has the ability to detect infections of unknown causes and emerging infectious diseases at boundary control points and in hospitals," Hong Kong's Centre for Health Protection Controller Dr Edwin Tsui said.

An earlier statement from Australia's Department of Agriculture said it was possible for virus from fruit bats to move into the country from South East Asia.

"Australia is currently free of Nipah virus, however, an incursion of this virus would have serious consequences for both animal and human health," the statement read.

"Over one million pigs were slaughtered in Malaysia in an attempt to control this disease."

title: Malaysian soccer bosses quit over disastrous 'cheating' scandal
text:
The entire executive committee of Malaysian soccer's governing body has "voluntarily" resigned over a scandal in which European and Latin American players were improperly granted citizenship to play for the national team.

A complaint was lodged against Football Association of Malaysia (FAM) last year after Malaysia beat regional rivals Vietnam 4-0 with several players who had only been granted citizenship the week before.

An investigation by FIFA concluded the men's grandparents were not born in Malaysia as claimed, but rather Spain, Argentina, Brazil and the Netherlands.

FIFA alleged FAM had "doctored" documents in order to field the players, ordering the association to pay a fine of 350,000 Swiss francs ($663,000).

A table lifted from a report shows names of footballers' grandparents and where FIFA found they were born in doctored versus original documentation. (ABC News: Jarrod Fankhauser)

"Presenting fraudulent documentation with the purpose of gaining eligibility to play for a national team constitutes, pure and simple, a form of cheating," FIFA's report said.

A statement from FAM yesterday announcing the resignations said it was "a prudent and principled step taken in light of the recent situation".

The executives had been elected for the term 2025 to 2029 but their unanimous "voluntary" exit was intended to restore the confidence of supporters, stakeholders and the football community, the statement said.

"Maintaining institutional credibility is essential for the stability, sustainability, and future development of Malaysian football," it said.

Court of arbitration clears suspended footballers to play

When FIFA handed down its findings last year, seven players were slapped with a 12-month suspension from football-related activities and individual fines of around $3,800.

The players whose family heritage was in question were Spanish-born Gabriel Palmera and Jon Irazabal; Facundo Garces, Rodrigo Holgado and Imanol Machuca born in Argentina; Brazil-born Joao Figueiredo; and Hector Hevel who was born in the Netherlands.

Five of the seven foreign-born players suspended by FIFA. (AFP: Mohd Rasfan/ABC News Graphic: Jarrod Fankhauser)

FIFA concluded the players were the "ultimate beneficiaries" and "illegally, and successfully enjoyed the consequences".

They have appealed FIFA's decision at the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which this week granted a stay on the 12-month ban until their appeal had been reviewed.

An in-person hearing for their appeal will be held at the Court of Arbitration's headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland in late February.

title: How to see more ABC News stories in Google Search
text:
Google is now letting you choose which publishers you want to see more of in your search results to give users a personalised experience.

Instead of the algorithm being in control, people in Australia are able to customise their results in Google Search with a feature called preferred sources.

When you select ABC News as your preferred source, you'll see more ABC articles displayed prominently within Google Top Stories, whenever fresh and relevant content for your search has been published.

Why choose ABC News?

ABC News is Australia's most trusted news provider.

We have local news teams across the country, along with specialist reporters covering politics, business, international news, climate, sport and regional issues.

Our expert reporters provide live updates on the biggest news stories and ABC News offers daily explainers on the day's biggest issues.

Here's a step-by-step guide to seeing more stories from the ABC when you search in Google.

How to select the ABC as your preferred source

Go to the Google search bar and type in a topic that's in the news. Click on the icon to the right of Top Stories (two overlapping cards with a star). Search for the ABC, then select it as your preferred source. Hit refresh, then you will start to see more stories from the ABC appear at the top of your search results.

Or you can click this link and follow the instructions.

It will take you to a page that looks like this, where you can add ABC News as your choice in source preferences.

title: State government backs out of central Queensland wind farm
text:
The state government has walked away from a central Queensland wind farm, saying it does not align with its energy road map but will instead partner with another wind farm in the state's north-west.

The Moah Creek Wind Farm, proposed by private developer Central Queensland Power (CQP), would be built on agricultural land 30 kilometres west of Rockhampton, with 60 turbines to power almost 200,000 homes.

Publicly owned generator CleanCo was in partnership to acquire the project.

However, it announced in a statement on Wednesday that it had assessed all projects in development and the Moah Creek Wind Farm did not align with its "current strategic activities, commercial portfolio and investment priorities, given changing energy market conditions".

CleanCo said it had withdrawn from further development and all delivery activities for Moah Creek Wind Farm but remained in discussion with CQP about a "potential future offtake opportunity".

The former Palaszczuk government announced in October 2023 that CleanCo had partnered with CQP and once development was completed, it would transition to public ownership.

It was CleanCo's first partnership since it was established in 2018.

A day after the company announced its withdrawal from the central Queensland project, the Crisafulli government said CleanCo had signed a 10-year agreement with Windlab in the state's north-west to secure 75 per cent of Kennedy Energy Park's wind energy output from 2028.

"We know the energy shift towards renewables can have a positive impact on regional communities, but only if it is done right," Treasurer David Janetzki said.

The Kennedy Energy Park is located near Hughenden between Mount Isa and Townsville, and includes a 12-turbine, 43-megawatt wind farm, more than 55,000 solar panels and 2 megawatts of battery storage.

Moah Creek Wind Farm still going ahead

Nick Holland, pictured with his wife Melanie and son, said he would see up to 20 wind turbines from the Moah Creek Wind Farm, with the closest 2 kilometres away. (ABC News: Scout Wallen)

Central Queensland Power, a joint venture between Energy Estate and Renewable Energy Systems, said its project would still progress.

"The Moah Creek project remains a well‑positioned project," director Matt Rebbeck said.

The project secured federal funding in October last year through the Australian Government Capacity Investment Scheme.

CQP would not disclose the amount of funding but has confirmed to the ABC that it remained in place and would be used going forward, but it was also open to another investor.

The Holland's 2,500-hectare farm at Wycarbah has been in Nick's family for generations. (ABC News: Scout Wallen)

Wycarbah grazier Nick Holland, who neighbours the project, last year submitted to the state government a petition with more than 1,000 signatures calling for the wind farm to be axed and the state to withdraw investment.

On Thursday, Mr Holland said he was relieved that CleanCo had withdrawn.

"It was not the right location, given the number of residents in the vicinity and the impact it would have on those," he said.

Mr Holland said other concerns included the visual impacts, construction phase, impact on locals, vegetation buffers and run-off.

"There's a large number of people that are in the vicinity of this project that all shared all their different concerns of how it would affect them," he said.

The Moah Creek Wind Farm project is currently under assessment through the federal government's Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC) Act.

It secured state government approval in 2023.

Heartland of wind farm woes

In May last year, the state government axed the $1bn wind farm project axed , 40 kilometres west of Rockhampton, five months after it had secured approval from the state planning department.

About 200 kilometres away between Rockhampton and Mackay, Andrew "Twiggy" Forrest's 100-turbine Clarke Creek Wind Farm $1 billion wind farm opens after three years of construction.

The Clarke Creek Wind Farm was approved before the LNP state government changed the legislation in 2025.

The new laws require new development applications to have public consultation and community benefit agreements with local councils, and must allow third-party appeal.

title: Live: Aussie men's doubles pair showdown ahead of women's semifinals
text:
Australian pair Jason Kubler and Marc Polmans have a chance on day 12 to make the men's doubles final at Melbourne Park, but the highlight of the day will come later with the women's singles semifinals.

Kubler and Polmans are up against Briton Luke Johnson and Poland's Jan Zielinski.

Tonight on Rod Laver Arena, there will be a marquee double-header, with two-time champion Aryna Sabalenka facing Elina Svitolina, followed by Elena Rybakina against Jessica Pegula.

title: Tasmania takes control of ore stockpile after Liberty Bell Bay defaults on loan
text:
The Tasmanian government has appointed receivers and managers to protect the manganese ore stockpile paid for by taxpayers at the Liberty Bell Bay smelter in the state's north.

Liberty Bell Bay is Australia's only manganese alloy smelter.

It was given a $20 million loan from the state government in August, $14.5 million of which was used to buy one 23,000-tonne shipment of ore which was delivered in October.

Despite this, operations at the troubled smelter have not resumed, after being paused indefinitely in May last year, with the company blaming ore supply issues and global price volatility.

The smelter was bought in 2020 by international company GFG Alliance, which is headed by British businessman Sanjeev Gupta.

Liberty Bell Bay operates a manganese alloy smelter in northern Tasmania. (ABC News: Owain Stia-James)

Minister for Business, Industry and Resources Felix Ellis said the move had been made following ongoing defaults under the state's loan agreement.

"Unfortunately, GFG has not delivered on its promises to Tasmanians and to its workers to restart operations, and the loan [has] not been repaid," he said.

"By securing the ore and not moving immediately to sell it, the government is maintaining options and providing opportunity for Liberty Bell Bay and interested parties to continue discussions about potential future operations at the site.

"We have engaged extensively with Liberty's owners over recent months, including on potential future pathways for the business.

The smelter, near George Town, is the only one in Australia that can process manganese alloy, used in steel-making. (Supplied: Liberty Steel Group)

" The state must act responsibly to protect public funds and ensure its secured position is maintained. "

The Tasmanian government said it remained open to working with Liberty Bell Bay.

Liberty Bell Bay has been contacted for comment.

Suppliers left unpaid, some considering closure as a result

The chief executive of the Bell Bay Advanced Manufacturing Zone, Susie Bower, said at least five businesses were collectively owed $1.3 million by Liberty Bell Bay.

"We have been working with suppliers for quite some time, since October last year," she said.

Some suppliers are still waiting on payments from Liberty Bell Bay. (ABC News: Kate Nickels)

"We found out last week that four [staff] have had to be let go from one business, and another business keeps ringing me every week saying: 'What is happening Susie? I may have to close my business.'"

"This has quite significant ramifications with Liberty's non-payment of our suppliers.

"Liberty really do now need to step up and actually tell us what the future of this site will hold."

Ms Bower said some businesses have not been paid since December.

"After December those payments have all stopped," she said.

"They are on a knife's edge."

title: Minister says 'mountain is falling off' on notorious transport route
text:
Farmers affected by the repeated closure of a key Mid North Coast route are sceptical about plans for an assessment of the notorious stretch of road.

The New South Wales government has announced a detailed corridor assessment of Waterfall Way and other roads between Bellingen and Dorrigo, nearly two weeks after a 200-tonne landslide closed the road.

Motorists relying on Waterfall Way have been at the mercy of weather events for decades, with the latest closure the fourth in the past 12 months.

A major landslip closed Waterfall Way in 2021. (Supplied: Transport for NSW)

The road is a key tourism and agricultural route between north-west NSW and the coast, vital for the transport of livestock, dairy and produce over the Great Dividing Range.

Murray Grey stud breeder Sue Francis sent cattle to the abattoir at Wingham on the morning of the latest closure.

What would normally be a three or four-hour trip turned into a 24-hour ordeal for her livestock and the driver transporting them.

Sue Francis's cattle was on a truck for 24 hours trying to get to the abattoir. (Supplied: Sue Francis)

"It's pretty hard to know that your cattle are on this sort of adventure," Ms Francis said.

"Yes the cattle have gone to slaughter, but we spend months making sure that that last day is one of comfort and as stress-free as possible."

Stress before slaughter, including during handling and transport, can reduce the quality of beef under the Meat Standards Australia (MSA) grading program.

"Because of the stress they went through, I doubt they will grade and fit into the MSA value grid," Ms Francis said.

" So I'll be losing probably a couple of hundred bucks per head on that load, as will everybody else who had cattle on that load. "

For dairy farmers on the Dorrigo Plateau, the closure added four hours to the round trip for tankers transporting milk to the processor at Raleigh.

Dairy farmer Julie Moore was forced to change her milking schedule due to the closure. (Supplied: Julie Moore)

"Lots of the tankers do two runs to Dorrigo a day, so it makes an extremely long day for the drivers," Julie Moore said.

"If they're driving that back road [through Grafton] later in the night, they're on unfamiliar roads.

"It's a sealed surface but it's still not a road you want to be driving a milk tanker around at night."

Solutions to be assessed

NSW Regional Transport and Roads Minister Jenny Aitchsion said she was meeting with engineers and technical experts to assess the corridor and explore possible solutions.

"It is a very difficult situation because the mountain is essentially falling off," she said.

"We've had 150 tonnes coming down over the initial 50 tonnes of material that fell.

"We understand the frustration, but we don't want a situation where the weight of 10 cars comes down and hits someone trying to go about their day."

Minister for Regional Transport and Roads Jenny Aitchison said short and long-term solutions would be considered. (ABC News: Romy Stephens)

Ms Aitchison said the NSW government had dedicated more than $100 million for remediation works to address slips in the area caused by severe weather in recent years.

While alternative routes connecting the Mid North Coast and Northern Tablelands were being explored, Ms Aitchison said it would not be a simple fix.

Crews are working to stabilise the active slope. (Supplied: NSW Government)

"We need to make sure we have the right data points in place and we do understand what the alternatives are," she said.

"We’re looking at different options to strengthen the surrounding network so we can provide a better option during times of natural disasters."

Farmers sceptical

The assessment is due to be completed by the middle of 2026.

Ms Moore said she would wait to see what concrete action came about as a result.

"There's been quite a few detailed studies done in the past 20 years and we're still at point A," she said.

" It's well and good for the assessment to be completed by the middle of the year, how many years will we then have to wait for the money to be allocated and work to commence? "

Ms Francis said short-term repairs were no longer suitable.

"The patching and the band-aids are not working," she said.

"If the assessment is done this year, perhaps they can promise that work will be starting on it by the end of this year as well."

title: Sabalenka has single focus with Open trophy beckoning
text:
Aryna Sabalenka is in very familiar territory after reaching her fourth successive semifinal at the Australian Open, but what's not familiar are her rivals left in the draw, including her last-four opponent Elina Svitolina.

Sabalenka has a third title at Melbourne Park in sight after sweeping past US teen prodigy Iva Jovic 6-3, 6-0 while Svitolina made similar short work of Coco Gauff.

With a politically-charged setting, there's no love lost between Sabalenka and outspoken Ukrainian Svitolina, who has pointedly refused to shake hands post-match with Russian or Belarusian opponents, including the world number one.

World number five Elena Rybakina was last in the Open semifinals in 2023 and has been joined by number six Jessica Pegula, with the pair also squaring off Thursday.

But the tournament has lost the usual grand slam heavyweights in Iga Świątek, Gauff and Amanda Anisimova.

Those three players — ranked two to four — were forced to pack their bags after all suffering quarterfinal losses.

Madison Keys, who shocked Sabalenka in last year's final to end her hat-trick run of titles, is also out after falling to Pegula in the fourth round.

The loss to Keys was Sabalenka's only reverse in her past 26 matches at Melbourne Park, including titles in 2023 and 2024. A third trophy would also move her to five majors.

That would draw her level with Martina Hingis and Maria Sharapova on the all‑time winners' list.

The Belarusian world number one said she didn't think about her stunning consistency when she was in the midst of a tournament.

"When I'm in the tournament, I'm not thinking about that, but sometimes we all stop for a second and we think the level we're able to reach, it sounds really incredible and tough to believe," the 27-year-old said.

Do you have a story idea about women in sport? Email us abcsport5050@your.abc.net.au

"I think what's really helping me to be there all the time is the focus that I'm having — focusing on the right things definitely helps a lot with the consistency."

Sabalenka said she didn't give too much energy to her opponent, believing that keeping the blinkers on was best for her own game.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

But she expected a tough battle with Svitolina, who is into her fourth major semi — and first since Wimbledon in 2023 — but is still chasing an elusive maiden grand slam title.

The former world number three has begun 2026 on a 10-match winning streak although Sabalenka has won the past four matches between the pair and five of six overall.

"It doesn't matter who is going to make it to the semis, it's going to be a battle because whoever makes it there, it's an incredible player," Sabalenka said.

"Every player when they get to the tournament it's the trophy or nothing but I'm trying to shift my focus on the right things and taking it step by step.

"My approach going to be the same — doesn't matter who I'm facing I'll just be focused on myself and on my game, and fight for every point."

AAP

title: Boys and girls detained together without access to health staff, report finds
text:
Male and female youth detainees in Alice Springs are being housed together for up to 72 hours without access to on-site health staff before being transferred to Darwin, prompting the Northern Territory Children's Commissioner to call for "urgent reform".

In a report released today, NT Children's Commissioner Shahleena Musk found "the overall trajectory of youth detention in the NT — particularly for Central Australian young people — has worsened" since the transfers of youth detainees from Central Australia to Darwin began in 2023.

Commissioner Musk said of the 60 Alice Springs Youth Detention Centre (ASYDC) detainees transferred to Darwin during the first 10 months of the plan, all were Aboriginal, while 10 were girls, and 16 either had been or were being assessed for a disability.

The report represents the second part of a two-part investigation into what was originally the temporary transfer of detainees from Alice Springs to Darwin in 2024, but Commissioner Musk said its relevance had "shifted significantly" since the NT government effectively closed the Alice Springs Youth Detention Centre early last year.

The Alice Springs Youth Detention Centre has effectively been closed, with detainees now held there for up to 72 hours before being transferred to Darwin. (ABC News: Xavier Martin)

In her report, Commssioner Musk wrote that since the Country Liberal Party (CLP) had taken office in the NT in September 2024, young detainees in Alice Springs were "routinely transferred to a facility over 1,500km away in Darwin, resulting in their disconnection from family, community and culture".

"The purpose-built ASYDC facility has been reduced to a single block for short term and transitionary detention of children, while the majority of the site and infrastructure is being adapted to an adult facility," the report reads.

"Concerningly, it is used to house male and female young people together and for short periods of up to 72 hours only.

"This measure is in place until a remand facility in Alice Springs is finalised, however the projected dates for completion of this new infrastructure continue to push out."

Shahleena Musk says a failure to act on her findings will only "compound the disadvantage faced by young people from Central Australia" and increase the likelihood of reoffending. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

The report states that the ASYDC's school has closed and there are "no longer health or clinical staff on site", while "serious deficiencies" have been identified "reflecting systemic weaknesses across the NT youth justice system".

"The concentration of youth detention in the one facility in Darwin undermines rehabilitation, family, community and cultural connection, and reintegration outcomes for Central Australian young people," Commissioner Musk wrote.

" Without urgent reform, the NT risks entrenching a system that is punitive, contra to best practice, and inconsistent with the rights of children under both domestic and international law. "

The commissioner also found families of youth detainees in Central Australia "are not being consulted and in some cases not contacted prior to their transfers to Darwin".

Department rejects all recommendations

In her report, Commissioner Musk made five recommendations she described as "reasonable and achievable", but all of which were rejected by the NT Corrections Department.

Commissioner Musk said their rejection would only "compound the disadvantage faced by young people from Central Australia" and increase the likelihood of reoffending.

In response to a recommendation to notify detainees' families when they were transferred to Darwin, the department said while there was "no legislative requirement" to do so, an "extensive review" of service standards was under way.

"We endeavour, to the extent possible, to ensure that young people remain in contact with family, without compromising our staff or centres' safety and operational functions," the department wrote.

An ABC investigation last week revealed there were nine self-harm incidents requiring hospitalisation at the Holtze Youth Detention Centre in the year after it opened. (ABC News: Jayden O'Neill)

The department also said the transfer process could be "unduly delayed" if staff were required to provide Indigenous language translators, in response to another recommendation.

"Detainees may go through the charging and court processes without the assistance of an interpreter and still enter into the youth detention system with an idea of why they are detained," the department wrote.

" All transfers are explained in the simplest manner possible, which includes the use of aids such as picture books. "

The department also defended its refusal to commit to adhere to its own policies, saying resources had been "stretched" following an "influx of detainees into the youth detention system".

Nine youths hospitalised after self-harm at new NT detention centre Nine youths ended up in hospital after self-harming at Darwin's new $130 million detention centre in the 12 months after it opened, documents released to the ABC under Freedom of Information laws have revealed.

"The department is dealing with a large cohort of young people, who enter and exit the youth justice system frequently, but are not in a stable position for long enough to allow thorough planning and preparations to occur," the department wrote.

"A lot of detainees have insufficient supports outside of a detention setting, despite the department's best planning and intentions."

In a statement also released today, Commissioner Musk said the department's response reflected a "missed opportunity" to ensure detainees were not further disadvantaged by the decision to consolidate the NT's youth justice centres.

“It is incredibly disappointing that the Department of Corrections has not accepted any recommendations made by the inquiry, including simply following their own existing policies and procedures, and committing to ensuring young people have access to interpreters for key decisions,” she said.

title: Gold Coast firm fined $14m over Qoin cryptocurrency
text:
A Gold Coast company that launched the Qoin crypto token in 2020 has been fined $14 million by the Federal Court for "serious and unlawful misconduct".

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) launched legal action against BPS Financial Limited in 2022, alleging it made false, misleading or deceptive representations to about 80,000 people or businesses.

On Tuesday, Justice Kylie Downes ordered BPS pay $14 million in pecuniary penalties, be prohibited from providing unlicensed financial services for 10 years, and publish a notice online outlining the court's decision.

"From January 2020 until mid-2023 the defendant, BPS Financial Pty Ltd (BPS) engaged in serious and unlawful misconduct," Justice Downes stated in the court judgement.

"During the same period, BPS issued more than 96,000 Qoin Wallets and derived substantial revenues totalling over $42 million from the sale of Qoin Tokens."

Qoin background

Qoin was advertised as a digital currency that could be traded exclusively Block Trade Exchange (BTX).

Qoin and BTX were owned by BPS and operated from the same Southport office.

Offices for Qoin and Block Trade Exchange (BTX) at Southport on the Gold Coast in 2022. (ABC Gold Coast: Dominic Cansdale)

BPS also claimed Qoin could be used to buy goods and services from a growing number of Australian businesses.

About 96,000 Qoin accounts — or wallets — were issued, according to Federal Court documents.

In November 2021, a class action consisting of Qoin users was launched, amid growing concerns that many businesses registered on Qoin's website did not accept it as payment and that it had lost all value.

It came as the volume of Qoin sold on BTX collapsed from a high of $700,000 per day to almost zero by the end of 2022.

Last year, BPS settled the class action by providing claimants with 4.3 million Qoin tokens.

In her judgement Justice Downs said "the value of Qoin Tokens is likely to be limited" but that the settlement was "better than nothing".

BPS conduct 'condemnable', court finds

ASIC launched separate legal proceedings against BPS in October 2022.

It alleged BPS did not have the proper financial services licence, that it had falsely claimed that the number of Qoin businesses was rising and that the token could be traded for dollars or other cryptocurrencies on an independent exchange.

In May 2024, the Federal Court found that BPS had engaged in misleading conduct but was exempt from holding an Australian Financial Services Licence for a 10-month period.

ASIC successfully appealed that exemption finding last year, and the penalty hearing was conducted in Brisbane this week.

BPS director Tony Wiese. (YouTube: Qoin)

ASIC had sought a $21-million penalty but BPS director Tony Weise told the Federal Court the company was on the "brink of insolvency".

In her judgement, Justice Downes stated the conduct of BPS was "condemnable".

She found it made false or misleading claims that Qoin could be exchanged for Australian dollars or other cryptocurrencies on an independent exchange.

Justice Downes also found the claims that Qoin could be used to purchase goods or services from a growing number of businesses, or that it had been officially approved, were also false or misleading.

"The decline was persistent and known to BPS, and the fact that the representation remained for 12 months, whether resulting from inadvertence or gross carelessness, is condemnable," Justice Downes stated in her judgement.

She also found BPS carried out a financial services business without holding an Australian Financial Services Licence.

title: Molineux named Healy's successor as Australian captain
text:
Sophie Molineux has been named Australia's new all-format captain, replacing the retiring Alyssa Healy.

Molineux, 28, debuted for Australia in 2018 in T20 cricket, playing her first ODI later that year and her first Test in the 2019 Ashes.

She will make her official captaincy debut at the SCG against India on February 15 in the first T20 of a multi-format series.

Molineux is the captain of Victoria and the Melbourne Renegades, and led her WBBL side to the title in 2024.

Tahlia McGrath and Ash Gardner will be Molineux's vice captains.

Sophie Molineux replaces Alyssa Healy in the top job. (Supplied: Cricket Australia)

"It's a real honour to be named Australian captain and something I'm incredibly proud of, especially following on from Alyssa, who's had such a huge impact on this team and the game," Molineux said.

"We've got a really strong group with plenty of natural leaders, alongside a lot of exciting talent coming through, and I'm really looking forward to working together as we keep evolving and pushing ourselves to the next level, while staying true to the identity that makes this team so special.

"I'm incredibly grateful for the trust that's been shown in me, and I'm excited to grow alongside this group of players and see what we can achieve together with Tahlia, Ash and the rest of the team."

Finger-spinning all-rounder Molineux has struggled with injury over recent years, missing significant stretches of cricket with knee and foot issues.

Head of performance and women's selector, Shawn Flegler, said Cricket Australia would continue to "manage Sophie's workload, prioritising key tournaments and major international series following injury challenges in recent seasons".

Australia will face India in three T20s, three ODIs and a Test match through February and March.

Star leg-spinner Alana King is a surprising omission from the T20 squad, while quick Megan Schutt has been left out of the ODI squad.

All-rounder Nicola Carey has been recalled to the ODI and T20 squads and is a chance to play her first international match since 2022.

WBBL breakout star Lucy Hamilton could make her Test debut, with her left-arm pace considered a point of difference by selectors.

Lucy Hamilton could make her Test debut against India. (AAP: Darren England)

"Nicola has had an impressive past couple of years in domestic cricket and has also performed well overseas in both England and India. She is an experienced player, with a strong skill set, and she will get an opportunity to test those skills as we build towards the T20 World Cup," Flegler said.

"Lucy is an exciting left-arm fast bowler who offers something different with the ball. She has worked hard on her game over the past few years and is someone we believe has a big future, while also benefiting from being around the group at this level.

"We're fortunate to have great depth in our spin-bowling stocks, with three world-class spinners already in the side, which unfortunately means Alana misses out on the T20 format on this occasion; however, she will play in the Governor-General's match.

"It was also a tough call with Megan, but at her best she remains an important part of the side, particularly with the T20 World Cup on the horizon."

title: A deadly virus has been re-detected in India. Asian countries are taking no chances
text:
Countries across Asia are stepping up health screening measures after cases of a deadly virus were detected in India.

Authorities in India, Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong and Malaysia have enacted new testing regimes after two people were detected with the Nipah virus in West Bengal.

The illness has a 40 to 75 per cent fatality rate in humans, depending on a country's capacity to test, trace and treat those infected, the World Health Organization (WHO) says.

However, while it can spread from person to person, it does not do this easily, and outbreaks are usually small and fairly contained, according to experts and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.

Here's what we know about the virus, how it spreads, its symptoms and what countries are doing about it.

What is Nipah virus?

Nipah virus is a zoonotic disease — one that spreads from animals to humans.

The virus sits in the same category as COVID-19 and Ebola and is most commonly spread by fruit bats.

The WHO says more specifically, the consumption of fruit or fruit products — such as raw date palm juice — containing urine or saliva from infected fruit bats has been the most likely source of infection.

Scientists in Bangladesh have previously caught bats to test them for the virus. (Reuters: Mohammad Ponir Hossain, file)

The virus can also spread between humans, generally between close contacts.

There is also some evidence it can spread to other animals, including pigs, dogs, cats, sheep and horses, according to the UK Health Security Agency.

It was first discovered in 1999 after an outbreak in pig farmers in Malaysia and Singapore.

Since then, outbreaks have occurred most years in Bangladesh and in India.

What are Nipah virus symptoms?

A sudden onset of flu-like symptoms is common for people with Nipah virus.

Its incubation period is usually between 4 and 21 days.

Climate change disease risk Climate change isn't just expanding the environments where deadly diseases can occur, it's also making their spread more likely as weather events become more extreme, researchers say.

Medical experts say pneumonia and other respiratory symptoms can also develop, but the most serious complication is encephalitis, or inflammation of the brain.

Patients who suffer encephalitis stemming from Nipah virus have a higher mortality rate.

People who recover may be left with permanent neurological damage, regular seizures and even personality changes.

In rare cases, the virus has been known to reactivate some time after a person has recovered from it.

There is no specific treatment for the virus currently, with intensive care the only option for those with serious infections.

There is also no vaccine licensed for use.

What is happening in India?

Indian health authorities said they had identified two people with the virus in West Bengal since December.

The National Centre for Disease Control said as a result it had "initiated prompt and comprehensive public health measures".

"A total of 196 contacts linked to the confirmed cases have been identified, traced, monitored, and tested. All traced contacts have been found asymptomatic and have tested negative," it said in a statement.

"Enhanced surveillance, laboratory testing, and field investigations were undertaken … which ensured timely containment of the cases."

Two Nipah cases have been identified in the Narayana Multispeciality Hospital in the eastern Indian state of West Bengal. (AP Photo)

The West Bengal cases are the state's first in nearly two decades, following five fatal infections in 2007, local media reported.

The Australian government's Smartraveller website advises that Nipah virus is one to be aware of in India and Bangladesh, but doesn't detail a specific risk following the new cases.

The Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations, a group that tracks emerging disease threats and funds the development of medical tools to protect against them, said that as of December, 750 cases had been recorded in all, and 415 of the patients died.

What are Asian countries doing about Nipah virus?

Authorities in Singapore and Hong Kong said they were initiating temperature checks at airports for passengers arriving from India.

Thailand earlier this week tightened airport screening measures, with neighbouring Malaysia following suit.

There are now designated parking bays for aircraft arriving in Thailand from areas with Nipah infections, its health ministry said, while passengers must complete health declarations before clearing immigration.

International arrivals at Suvarnabhumi International Airport in Bangkok face extra screenings following the outbreak in India. (Suvarnabhumi Airport Office /Handout via Reuters)

Malaysia's health ministry said it was boosting preparedness through health screening at international ports of entry, particularly for arrivals from countries deemed at risk.

China's disease control authority said no Nipah infections had been detected in the country but there were risks of imported cases, state broadcaster CCTV reported on Tuesday.

Nepal, which shares a busy border with India, said it was on "high alert" and had tightened screening for travellers.

Health ministry officials said border points with India and China had been notified to remain vigilant and check suspected cases.

How can you avoid Nipah virus?

The WHO recommends several measures to decrease your risk of catching the virus, should you be travelling in areas where it is known to be occurring.

Active outbreaks of the virus in humans have only been registered in rural or semi-rural areas in India and Bangladesh in recent years.

Philippines, Singapore and Malaysia have also had outbreaks in the past.

It says avoiding bats and infected animals is key, along with washing and peeling fruit before eating it.

Discarding fruit that has bat bite marks or has fallen to the ground in areas with fruit bats is also recommended.

Maintaining proper hygiene is important for those who come into contact with infected people.

ABC/wires

title: 'Enough is enough:' Residents want home buyback scheme
text:
Home owners living beside the world's biggest hard-rock lithium mine in Western Australia's South West region are calling on the miner to buy out their homes or offer relocation.

Many locals in the historical mining town of Greenbushes, 240 kilometres south of Perth, have struggled to coexist with the mine in recent years because of regular blasting, dust and noise pollution.

The Greenbushes mine — owned by the Sino-American company Talison Lithium — provides nearly 20 per cent of the world's hard-rock lithium supply, which is crucial to the energy transition.

Trevor Stallard has lived in Greenbushes for 39 years, and he spent 15 of them working at the lithium mine.

Trevor Stallard says locals feel trapped by a comparatively sluggish property market in the town. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

The retired miner has decided that enough is enough.

"We didn't sign up for this," he said.

"The constant noise, the dust, the traffic early in the morning. The tremors twice a day."

Residents say a mining blast on Sunday, January 11, rocked the town site. (Supplied)

The big blast

The final straw for Mr Stallard and some other residents was a big mining blast on January 11, which reverberated across the town.

Local Rick Fryer described it as "the mother of all blasts".

"It frightened the daylights out of so many people," he said.

" It just slowly formed into this massive, massive cloud. "

The self-described "newbie" has lived in Greenbushes for the past 15 years.

Rick Fryer says dust from the mine is a constant nuisance. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

"I knew there was a mine here when we moved here nearly 15 years ago, but it wasn't this mine. Not the way it's operating now," Mr Fryer said.

"A lot of the residents, old-time residents, too, are really upset about what's happening to the town, to our town."

A Talison Lithium spokesperson said the blast recorded 124 linear decibels (dBL), which breached the mine's Sunday noise limit of 120 dBL.

"This was Talison's first reportable breach of the airblast limit since that was set in our licence conditions approved in 2015," the company said.

The company said the typical blast would measure 100 dBL, making the January 11 explosion "considerably more noticeable".

Talison Lithium says the January 11 blast breached its noise limit and was reported to the regulator. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

An internal and external investigation concluded that a routine "pre-split" blast, a critical technique used to cleanly break rock away from the pit wall, was the cause, according to the company.

Talison Lithium said it had already implemented several changes to the way it conducted such blasts.

The ABC has spoken to home owners who believe the regular and repeated vibrations from mine blasting have damaged ceilings and cracked drywalls.

The company said that while some impacts were inherent to mining, it was committed "to do better and be a good neighbour".

The cumulative effects of dust, traffic and noise have ignited calls for a home buyback scheme. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

Home owners want buybacks

The recent blast has stirred further discontent as the mounting effects of the noise, traffic and dust take a toll on the town's residents.

Some residents have complained of persistent coughs, watering eyes, and the nuisance of having to deal with the thin white dust coating cars and homes.

Mr Stallard said the mine's impacts had intensified since approved production capacity increased to 2.8 million tonnes of lithium concentrate a year in 2019.

"I intended to live here the rest of my life, I really did," Mr Stallard said.

"But it's got to the stage where everything's incessant, and it's not going to stop.

"Sooner or later you just go, 'Enough's enough.'"

Mr Stallard wants the mine to set up a voluntary home buyback or relocation scheme to help locals leave town.

Talison's mining operation supplies 20 per cent of the world's lithium. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

Northern Star Resources set up such a scheme in 2021 for residents in the suburb of Williamstown, on the edge of Kalgoorlie's Super Pit gold mine.

Talison Lithium said it planned to operate for "decades to come", and that it would take time and meaningful consultation to develop a shared vision for the future with the community.

"It is too early to determine what will be recommended, but nothing should be ruled out," the spokesperson said.

However, some locals feel their window of opportunity is closing as surrounding property markets outpace Greenbushes.

The town has a population of about 365 people, and the median house price is $395,000, compared to $595,000 at Balingup, just 11km away.

"A lot of them feel like they're trapped here because their house prices aren't going to go up," Mr Stallard said.

"They can't afford to buy elsewhere."

Talison Lithium wants to be a "good neighbour" as it plans to continue its operations for decades to come. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

'A good neighbour'

The miner has its eyes set on further expansion.

WA's environmental authority is considering Talison Lithium's proposal to increase its development envelope by more than 25 per cent.

Since Rob Telford was appointed Talison's chief executive in late 2024, the company has adopted a markedly conciliatory tone in its community relations.

Mr Telford has previously told the ABC he wants the mine to set the benchmark for transparency and community engagement.

Rob Telford has introduced a raft of measures to reduce impacts on nearby residents. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

Talison does not shy away from discussing its impacts and has previously expressed "deep regret" for them.

"We know we need to do better, and we are taking further steps to reduce impacts," a public statement read after the January 11 blast.

Following community criticism last year, the company introduced a raft of measures, including real-time public dust monitoring, expanded dust suppression, and noise reduction on haul trucks, among other things.

Dust level exceedence attributed to the mine halved from eight incidents in 2024 to four last year, according to the company.

Talison is also rebuilding Stanifer Street, a thoroughfare for haul trucks through the middle of town.

The company said it had considered ways to divert traffic away from the town, but it did not progress due to "design challenges" and the potential to create additional impacts.

Rick Fryer says the company needs to do more to address its impacts on locals. (ABC South West WA: Jon Daly)

But it is not good enough for Mr Fryer, who wants a bypass road built to divert traffic away from his home on Stanifer Street.

"It's very easy to say sorry after you do something," he said.

Mr Stallard believes managing the effects of a world-leading mining operation on the doorstep of a small community is impossible.

"I think they're doing everything they can. It's just not enough," he said.

"It's physically impossible to stop it."

title: Council chief says Alice Springs mall project signals 'strong future'
text:
Key spaces in the centre of Alice Springs are set for a face lift over the next few years, with several redevelopment projects in the pipeline bringing hope for the town's future.

The Alice Springs Town Council is working to renew the famous Todd Mall, the library, the visitor information centre, Leichhardt Terrace, and the area connecting Parsons Street to the Hartley Street car park.

Private stakeholders have plans to develop a shopping centre in the heart of town, while the Northern Territory government has announced a new multi-sport precinct to be built in Gillen.

Gum tree-shaped arbours will provide shade over the mall. (Supplied: Alice Springs Town Council)

Council chief executive Andrew Wilsmore said the projects were a "strong sign of faith" in the town, following the scrapping last year of plans for the multimillion-dollar Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Gallery of Australia in Alice Springs.

"We have got so many projects going on at the moment … it's a real show of faith that this is a town with a very strong future," he said.

The $20 million Todd Mall redevelopment will involve the mall's red bricks being replaced with white pavers, 12 trees removed and another 20 planted, a digital display board, a 10-metre sculpture installed on the church lawns, new seating, lighting, bubblers, bins, bike racks and toilets, and arbours designed to look like gum trees to cast shade over the pedestrian-heavy area.

The work is expected to be finished by the end of 2026.

Twelve trees will be removed, but another 20 will be planted in the redeveloped mall. (Supplied: Alice Springs Town Council)

"We've also designed for a couple of other aspects around town; that's the Leichhardt Terrace, some of the Parsons Street connectivity and all the way through to the Todd Street," Mr Wilsmore said.

"Those are shovel-ready projects, and if we can secure additional funding, we'll see those brought to life.

"I have a trip planned to Canberra to try to keep those funds that were originally destined for the art gallery to actually stay here in Alice Springs."

Andrew Wilsmore says the redevelopments are positive for Alice Springs. (ABC Alice Springs: Victoria Ellis)

Makeover for popular shopping centre

Redevelopment plans for the Yeperenye Shopping Centre, which sits between Hartley and Bath streets, would result in the building growing to include a four-level car park with more than 200 parking bays, a new loading dock and click-and-collect facilities.

Yeperenye managing director Owen Cole said the $27 million redevelopment would include office spaces and a rooftop bar and restaurant.

The design for Yeperenye Shopping Centre's redevelopment. (Supplied: Owen Cole)

"We own office spaces around Alice Springs … so we've got our finger on the pulse; the demand is there," he said.

"We think tourists and locals alike will rush to participate in (a new non-licensed restaurant)."

Owen Cole, the managing director of Yeperenye Shopping Centre in Alice Springs. (ABC Alice Springs: Victoria Ellis)

Supermarket giant Woolworths has been operating at the Yeperenye Shopping Centre for nearly 40 years, but will move to the Alice Plaza at the northern end of the Todd Mall in February 2028, at the end of its current lease.

Mr Cole said he had been in conversation with other supermarkets, such as Foodland, to move into the void left by Woolworths, but he ruled out retailer Aldi as an option.

The design for Yeperenye Shopping Centre's redevelopment. (Supplied: Owen Cole)

"We'd love to have an Aldi, but unfortunately they've already indicated on several occasions that they can't come to the Territory because it's too far from their distribution centre, the closest of which is in Adelaide," he said.

Mr Cole said the redevelopment was expected to be completed by September 2027.

Further work in the pipeline

Alice Springs Town Council and the Northern Territory government will spend $20 million on a new library to be built at the Civic Centre site above the council car park, due to the library outgrowing its current space.

The new library is planned to include more seating, study zones, collaborative spaces, and larger areas for children's programs, while also meeting accessibility and safety standards, supporting modern technology and digital services, and delivering a more comfortable space for the community.

The Alice Springs Public Library needs more space after 40 years in its current location. (ABC News: Elsie Lange)

Mr Wilsmore said there would be extensive community consultation before any design works were finalised.

Tourism Central Australia, which currently operates the visitor information centre at the Todd Mall, will move into the library space and take over the entire current library building once the new library is built.

title: Seven players ejected after brawl in 36ers win over Bullets
text:
Furious Adelaide coach Mike Wells has slammed the "dangerous" actions of two Brisbane imports after a wild scuffle led to seven ejections in the 36ers' blowout NBL win.

The ladder-leading 36ers punched their in-season Ignite Cup final ticket with a 107-74 Wednesday night victory, winning three of four quarters on the Gold Coast to collect enough points to book their spot in the February 22 spectacle against the New Zealand Breakers for a share in $400,000 prize money.

Wells was more concerned by what he claimed were punches thrown late in the final quarter after Bullets guard Hunter Maldonado tangled with Sixers big Nick Rakocevic to prompt an all-in scuffle.

The pair wrestled into empty chairs in the front row before Brisbane guard Terry Taylor arrived and put Rakocevic, who has already been suspended once this season, in a headlock.

All three were ejected while Bullets foursome Tristan Devers, Taine Murray, Alex Ducas and Sam McDaniel — the latter pair both inactive players out with injuries — were also marched from the building for joining from the bench.

In a statement, the NBL said the on-court incident has been referred to its Game Review Panel "for consideration in accordance with the NBL Tribunal Rules".

"Relevant parties will be notified of the next steps in the process," the statement read.

"No further comment will be made by the NBL while the matter is under review."

Wells struggled to contain his emotions post-game, slamming the actions of Maldonado and Taylor.

"By the time I got down there … Terry Taylor had Nick in a headlock in his back and Maldonado was punching him in the stomach," he claimed.

"That's not basketball. This is a hard-playing league … [but] that crossed the line.

"It concerned me … it rattled all of us. He's [Taylor] got a choke-hold … holding a guy by the neck. That is really dangerous.

"I was really scared for my player. I screamed at Terry, almost like a parent, like 'What are you doing?'.

"And Maldonado … he was not stopping. I am fired up and a little concerned."

In a post-game press conference, Mike Wells says he was "fired up and a little concerned". (ABC News)

The incident left the already injury-ravaged Bullets with one player on the bench, the 36ers awarded four free-throws and kicking on in the fourth quarter.

The 33-point loss was Brisbane's 16th from their last 17 games and follows losses of 32 and 38 points in their last two contests.

Adelaide sharp-shooter DJ Vasiljevic stoked the flames further, describing the Bullets' actions as "unprofessional".

"Throwing cheap shots at us because they're going to finish last. I hope the league looks into it," he said.

Interim coach refutes Adelaide's claims

But interim Brisbane coach Darryl McDonald refuted Adelaide's claims.

"I saw Rakocevic like, power drive Maldonado [into the ground]," he said.

"Guys protecting each other … nobody threw punches. He [Maldonado] was trying to get away from the guy.

"Go to the tape, have a look."

Bullets forward Jacob Holt had a career-high 24 points in another promising display while Adelaide were led by new import John Jenkins (19 points) and the irrepressible Bryce Cotton (22 points, seven assists, five rebounds).

Isaac Humphries and Flynn Cameron both had 16 points as the visitors shared the load.

A 39-point final term blew the lead out after the Brisbane had won the second quarter and trailed by just six at the main break.

AAP/ABC

title: Australian Open 2026 LIVE updates: Aussies in doubles semis; Svitolina takes on world No.1 Sabalenka; Pegula to battle against Rybakina
text:
If you thought Novak Djokovic was having the craziest tournament of his life with two of his AO 2026 opponents retiring hurt before his stroll into the semis, think again.

Ten years ago, at the US Open, the Djoker benefited from several retirements and a walkover.

Lorenzo Musetti embraces Novak Djokovic after retiring hurt from their quarter-final. Credit: AP

In the second round that year, Jiri Vesely withdrew before their match due to an arm injury.

Mikhail Youzhny retired during the third round while trailing 4-2 in the first set, due to a leg injury.

Once Djokovic reached the quarter-finals, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga retired while trailing 6-3, 6-2 due to a knee injury.

But none of this was enough for the tennis legend to lift the US Open crown. He eventually lost in the final to our favourite AO retiree, Swiss star Stan Wawrinka, 7-6, 4-6, 5-7, 3-6.

Can Djokovic lift the Open crown for the record 11th time this year? Stick with us as the slam continues to find out.

title: Pacgold broadens massive gold-antimony system in Qld
text:
Advertisement

Sponsored BusinessCompaniesBulls N' Bears Pacgold broadens massive gold-antimony system in Qld Brought to you by BULLS N’ BEARS Rowena Duckworth January 29, 2026 — 1:27pm Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Pacgold Limited has kept the drill bit busy and the excitement ticking over at its St George gold–antimony project in North Queensland, wrapping up its maiden reverse circulation (RC) drilling program with another set of shallow, high-grade antimony hits. The company says the new results have added weight to the idea that a much larger mineralised system may be lurking below the surface. Gold and stibnite in quartz vein at Pacgold Limited’s St George project in Northern Queensland. The first-pass nine-hole RC campaign, completed late last year, was designed to poke a few holes beneath historic workings at a once-forgotten antimony field that had already been flashing serious promise at surface. While the mineralised trend runs for more than a kilometre, drilling to date has tested just 200 metres of strike and even that light touch has delivered plenty of fireworks. The results from the last seven holes are now in. Two particular drill holes confirmed that antimony-rich quartz veins don’t stop at surface. Standout hits included 1 metre at 12.8 per cent antimony from 41m downhole. A second intercept returned 3m running at 1.6 per cent antimony from 67m and included a richer 1-metre slice grading a stunning 4.4 per cent antimony from 68m.

Advertisement

‘The upside of this vast tenement package is immense.’ Pacgold Limited managing director Matthew Boyes Gold made its presence felt as well, adding extra shine to the story. Hits included a solid 8m grading 0.7g/t gold from 45m downhole and in another drillhole, the bit struck 1m at a steady 1.3g/t gold from 82m. Shallow mineralisation was also intersected, with 7m running at 0.5g/t gold from just 4m downhole in a third hole, including a 2m zone grading 1.2g/t gold from 8m depth. All up, seven of the nine RC holes drilled delivered anomalous antimony or gold - a tidy strike rate for a maiden program that barely scratched the edges of the system. Notably, the quartz veins remain open along strike to the north and south and down dip, leaving plenty of blue sky for follow-up drilling. The nine-hole program totalled 826 metres and intersected multiple north-trending quartz veins hosted in interbedded sandstone and shale, with widespread sericite alteration pointing to a fertile hydrothermal system. Historic records show the area previously produced about 60 tonnes of ore grading a staggering 60 per cent antimony from open pit and shallow underground workings during the 1960’s - proof that the rocks here know how to deliver.

Advertisement

And St George isn’t a one-trick pony. The broader geological story shows Pacgold’s tenure sits within a major north-northwest–trending structural corridor that stretches for more than 20 kilometres and hosts multiple additional gold–antimony targets. These include the company’s Fence and Ridgeline gold-antimony prospects. Together with St George, the three prospects form part of a mineralised belt extending for more than 20 kilometres of strike across Pacgold’s tenement package. Pacgold Limited managing director Matthew Boyes said “Intersecting additional high grade antimony numbers confirms we have a large mineralised system which we have only just started to explore. The upside of this vast tenement package is immense, and 2026 is shaping up to be a massive year for our exploration crews.” The timing of these results couldn’t be better. Antimony has been thrust into the global spotlight as a critical mineral thanks to its role in defence, energy storage and advanced manufacturing, while gold prices continue to surge to new highs almost daily, supercharging the economics of any discovery that can grow scale and grade. With the North Queensland wet season temporarily slowing boots-on-the-ground fieldwork and drilling, Pacgold plans to return to St George in the June quarter with an expanded drill plan. The company says it plans to chase extensions beneath historic workings and fan out along the broader corridor to test a suite of high-priority regional targets. With shallow, high-grade antimony confirmed, gold along for the ride and kilometres of fertile ground still untouched, Pacgold looks to have plenty of reasons to be sharpening the drill bits ahead of what shapes as a very busy 2026.

Advertisement

As antimony surges up government agendas and gold prices soar due to geopolitical uncertainty, the drilling at St George appears to be hitting the right rocks at exactly the right time. Is your ASX-listed company doing something interesting? Contact: mattbirney@bullsnbears.com.au
